Story and Characters
One of the most striking aspects of Modern Warfare is its narrative. The game presents a gritty, contemporary storyline that feels both relevant and thought-provoking. Set against the backdrop of a fictional conflict in the Middle East and Eastern Europe, the campaign tackles complex themes such as terrorism, moral ambiguity, and the gray areas of warfare. The writing is sharp, with well-developed characters that you genuinely care about.

You follow multiple protagonists, including Sergeant Kyle "Gaz" Garrick and the fierce, resilient Farah Karim, whose personal stories intertwine with larger geopolitical conflicts. The character development is impressive, making the players emotionally invested in their journeys and decisions. The voice acting is superb, adding depth and authenticity to the characters.

Gameplay Mechanics
Modern Warfare offers a polished and engaging gameplay experience. The mechanics feel tight and responsive, whether you're navigating the chaos of a battlefield or executing a stealthy infiltration. The game successfully balances traditional Call of Duty fast-paced action with moments that require strategic thinking and careful planning.

The gunplay is satisfying and feels grounded, with a wide array of weapons that can be customized to fit your playstyle. The introduction of a gunsmith system allows for extensive weapon modifications, adding a layer of personalization that enhances the gameplay experience.

Graphics and Sound Design
Visually, Modern Warfare is a stunning achievement. The graphics are breathtaking, with meticulously crafted environments that draw players into the experience. From the urban landscapes to the gritty interiors of war-torn buildings, every detail is polished to perfection. The lighting effects, in particular, create a sense of realism that heightens the immersion.

The sound design is equally impressive, with realistic weapon sounds and atmospheric audio that captures the intensity of battle. The score complements the action beautifully, enhancing emotional moments and providing a thrilling backdrop to the chaos.

Multiplayer Experience
The multiplayer component of Modern Warfare revitalizes the classic Call of Duty formula while introducing new elements that keep players engaged. The maps are diverse, offering a variety of playstyles, from close-quarters combat to long-range engagements. The introduction of new game modes, including Gunfight, provides fresh experiences that encourage tactical teamwork.

Moreover, the game emphasizes cross-platform play, allowing friends to team up regardless of their console. This feature broadens the player base and fosters a more inclusive gaming community. The progression system is rewarding, giving players a sense of achievement as they unlock new gear and upgrades.

Conclusion
Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) is a masterful blend of nostalgia and innovation. It respects the legacy of its predecessors while boldly charting a new course for the series. The campaign's gripping narrative, compelling characters, and immersive gameplay set a high standard for first-person shooters. Coupled with a robust multiplayer experience and stunning visuals, Modern Warfare has solidified its place as one of the standout titles in the franchise.

Whether you’re a long-time fan or new to the series, Modern Warfare offers a captivating experience that keeps players coming back for more. This game not only redefines what players expect from a Call of Duty title but also reaffirms the franchise’s status as a leader in the genre.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) reinvents the franchise while paying homage to its roots, delivering an experience that is both thrilling and immersive. The campaign is a standout, featuring a gripping narrative that explores the moral complexities of modern warfare. The characters are well-developed, and the missions are varied and intense, keeping you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

The graphics are stunning, with realistic environments and meticulous attention to detail that enhances the overall atmosphere. Each location feels authentic, whether you’re in a war-torn city or a stealthy nighttime operation. The sound design is equally impressive, with impactful audio that adds depth to every gunshot and explosion.

Multiplayer is where Modern Warfare truly shines. The game offers a range of modes, from classic team deathmatch to the expansive Ground War, which accommodates large-scale battles. The gunplay feels refined and satisfying, with a wide selection of weapons and customization options that cater to various playstyles. Plus, the cross-platform functionality allows you to team up with friends, regardless of their gaming platform.

The addition of the Gunfight mode is a breath of fresh air, providing fast-paced, 2v2 matches that test skill and strategy. It's a fantastic way to jump into action without the long commitments of larger matches.

Overall, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) is a remarkable entry in the series that combines cinematic storytelling with high-octane gameplay. Whether you’re a longtime fan or a newcomer, this game offers something for everyone. Highly recommended for those seeking an engaging and action-packed gaming experience!

I consider Call of Duty: Modern Warfare like the Renaissance period, for having brought Call of Duty once again to his former glory.

Though, judging by the sequels that followed this game, that supremacy didn't last long, it was nevertheless awesome to see Call of Duty to be the hottest thing in the gaming world one more time.

Call of Duty ounce again deploys the Modern Warfare series to ground the series and reflect modern times. It really is a step forward in many ways.

The gunplay feels punchy and weightier than ever before, creating gun feedback that feels almost brutal in achieving the cool feeling of shooting guns. It is at it's release the best feeling CoD, weapons no longer feeling like air soft guns, but true mechanical killing sticks. 

It's presentation is top tier, invoking modern films such as 13 Hours and Zero Dark Thirty. Depicting a warzone that is not big battles of moving armies and mechanical movements, but more strategic strikes, terrorism, and in general more believable. Toning down the 80s/90s action movie vibe. It's rendered amazingly at times, looking life like at plenty of times. 

It's sound design capturing the grittiness. 

The problem is many of these missions are rather dry and boring and its attempts at creative missions often just dull.

"Solid Campaign, Great Optimization, but Multiplayer Needs Balancing"

I’ve really enjoyed Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2019 so far, especially the campaign. The story line is incredibly gripping and well-paced, It’s one of the best campaigns I’ve played in the series, and it was worth every penny just for that experience.

On the technical side, the game is also really well-optimized. I haven’t faced any major performance issues, and it runs smoothly on my rig.

As for multiplayer, I haven’t played too much yet (currently around level 20), but the matchmaking feels a bit off. I keep getting matched with level 1000+ players, which makes it tough to enjoy sometimes. 
Hopefully, the balancing improves as I rank up.

Overall, I’d definitely recommend it, especially if you’re into a solid single-player campaign!

‣ 8/10 – Finally played the campaign.

‣ Thoughts: A few years back I played Warzone and enjoyed it, until I’ve decided to buy the actual game and do the campaign. Funny enough after completing my purchase and loading up the game I got permanently banned due to having unrevealed by Activision cheating programs on my pc. Turns out the fantastic Ricochet anti-cheat system thought my Logitech app and all the other RGB controlling files were cheats. So, they outright banned me and didn’t give a shit about my appeal. After that cursed day, I vouched to never purchase an Activision game again and move on with my life. Well things change, I guess.

After being blue balled for 4 years and unable to experience the now goated Call of Duty campaign I caved and attempted to play Modern Warfare again. Thank fuck I did not get banned and had a blast. So yes, fuck this company and everything they do, but goddamn it they made a great single-player fps experience. I’m not really invested in the characters and the lore of CoD: Modern Warfare, but what I did get was interesting enough to keep me engaged. We all know how fun and exciting the campaign is, but I did not expect it to have so much variety when it comes to gadgets and weapons you get to use.

Overall, this is just a simple campaign review, and I don’t think you need me to tell you how good it is. Everything is executed really well. I just expected a bigger and more cinematic ending with more fleshed out villains and characters. But seems like the developers had other plans to milk the franchise into the ground. Spoiler alert, they did.

I found Call of Duty: Modern Warfare  to be an impressive game overall, with a lot to love but also a few frustrations. The visuals are stunning, and the gunplay is some of the best in the series, with weapons feeling powerful and realistic. The single-player campaign is gripping, with some truly intense missions that kept me engaged. Multiplayer offers a lot of variety, from fast-paced close-quarters combat to larger-scale battles, and the weapon customization through Gunsmith is a great touch.

However, there are a few things I disliked. The spawning system in multiplayer can be frustrating at times, leading to some unfair deaths. Spec Ops mode, while fun in concept, feels a bit underdeveloped and lacks the polish of the other modes. There are also occasional performance issues on lower-end systems, though nothing too game-breaking.

Despite these issues, I’d still recommend Modern Warfare to anyone looking for an immersive and fast-paced shooter. Whether you’re a veteran of the series or new to Call of Duty, there’s plenty here to enjoy. Just be aware of the minor flaws, and you’ll have a great experience.

By far, the absolute best Call Of Duty ever made. The weapons are fantastic, the story was gritty with a sense of realism and the graphics were too notch. This is first Multiplayer I’ve given well over a hundred hours to in years. Generally, the multiplayer is pretty boring with few unlocks to care about...Cold War... but almost every unlock and score streak felt amazing to use. Even if some guns weren’t as competitive as others, I still enjoyed using them the challenge and fun. Infinite ward also changed the multiplayer meta in a way that made it feel real but also like an arcade. Infinite Ward set the bar for all other games to come after it. Unfortunately, Cold War has since fallen well behind modern warfare’s shadow. While not every COD will be the same going forward, I truly hope that they learn from how amazing modern warfare is. Crossplay is both a welcomed introduction and cursed one. On one hand, it’s awesome to play with friends regardless of their system and it makes for more populated games.

I have played every single COD game ever since Call of Duty 2 from nearly two decades ago, and I can confidently say that this Modern Warfare title was by far my favorite. The story line was out of a blockbuster movie, the graphics were incredible and the weapons physics were extremely realistic. Everything that I ever loved in Call of Duty titles were perfectly implemented in this title, I would definitely recommend anyone who loves the Call of Duty series or any other shooters to play this game.

The only downside is that the campaign is short (around 6 hours) for a game that costs $60, however I would still recommend spending a little extra buck to enjoy this game to the fullest. 

P.S. the optimization was the best from any other game I have ever experienced since I was able to get over 200FPS with a mid-tier PC on Ultra Graphics.

COD: Modern Warfare (2019) is like your favorite fast food restaurant: you know you shouldn't go there, but you just can't resist. The game is like an old friend that you meet again after years and immediately starts shouting: 'Let's blow things up and steal a tank!' But then you suddenly remember why you ever fled him...

The graphics? Well, it's like watching an action movie that someone is very proud of, but sometimes you wonder if it hasn't all been taken a little too seriously. The environments are beautiful and detailed, but after a while everything starts to look the same - full of rubble, smoke and of course, more rubble.

The campaign has a story that your mother would even find exciting, if she hadn't fallen asleep halfway through. It revolves around the usual themes: terrorists, conspiracies, and of course, the mysterious button that can blow everything up. Sometimes you feel like the game is attacking your IQ, but thankfully that's made up for by the explosions - so many explosions.

And the multiplayer? It's hectic, chaotic, and filled with twelve-year-old snipers who will take you out in five seconds. But hey, that's part of the charm, right? It's a game of 'who shoots first', where you lose more often than you'd like to admit.

And the servers? They are as stable as a wobbling tower of Jenga bricks in an earthquake. Every time you think you've finally got a decent connection, you're kicked out, as if the game itself is saying, "Enough fun for today!"

So if you're looking for a game that will evoke your nostalgia in a comedic way, Modern Warfare (2019) is the perfect choice. But if you're looking for something innovative... maybe look further. Unless of course you're into nostalgic chaos. In that case, see you on the battlefield, soldier!

I really liked this game.  The 2019 version of COD: Modern Warfare has a fantastic storyline, good play, and could easily have been one of the best Call of Duty games made.  
So why don't I recommend it?  The incessant bugs and crashes.  
My system can play any game out there with no problem, and this game is five years old.  Yet there were lots of freezes in high-action areas; plus most of the cutscenes would replay once you're supposed to start your mission, which means the game is playing but the cutscene is also playing, making it impossible to play without forcing a skip and missing the start of each mission (and hoping you don't get killed in the process).
Despite everything that was so good with this game, the bugs made it near unplayable at times.  And this is FIVE YEARS LATER.  The developers just didn't care enough to make some simple fixes.
In short, the game itself is actually really good and if you're a COD purist like me, it's worth getting annoyed at over and over again just to get the storyline.  But overall the technical glitches are fairly major and enough for me to say it should probably be skipped.

Warning to all players who are upgrading their PCs and experiencing crashes while playing Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2019! or CODMW3 ETC. All my other games are fine and I am not banned on MW3 and can play it. I recently upgraded my PC with high-end components, including an Intel 14th Gen processor and DDR5 RAM. However, I started experiencing crashes while playing the game, I even updated my Asus prime motherboard bios to help and to my surprise, I was permanently banned without any explanation. I don't know what happened. I hadn't played this one for about a year or two but let it update along with MWIII and the others i have purchased on battlenet. I thought this was a fluke i purchased the game on steam and still same thing showed banned account??

I suspect that the Ricochet anti-cheat software may have mistaken the crashes for something malicious, but I've also experienced crashes in other games without being banned. It's incredibly frustrating to be banned without any warning or explanation, especially when it seems to be related to something outside of my control. Where is my email explaining the ban or violation. or date of violation and what was done. 

Activision's support has been unresponsive and unhelpful, making it difficult to appeal the ban or get any resolution. I'm posting this review to warn other players who may be experiencing similar issues, and to urge Activision to reconsider their ban policies and provide more transparency and support to their players. Please be cautious when upgrading your PC and playing Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2019, as you may be at risk of being unjustly banned. Do i recommend this game yes if they fix problem no if they wont fix it. Its just not fair for honest players really wanting to enjoy game. MW19 is the last good call of duty game, if you want a good campaign, multiplayer or co-op, get this game, don't fall for the other 2 mw games cause those fumbled the ball hard. 
MULTIPLAYER:

 It's amazing.
The multiplayer to my knowledge isn't infested with hackers and it's actually a lot of fun.. the gunsmith is good and you don't need to level up one gun to unlock one gun to get 1 optic for a different gun...

CAMPAIGN:

The campaign is fantastic. I played through the whole thing without getting bored and playing on my phone like the other 2 mw games. The campaign is actually really well put together with better graphics than most cods nowadays. The campaign is about 4 or 5 hours long with really good storytelling, cutscenes and dialogue.

CO-OP:

I really didn't play much of co-op, it didn't really look good to me imo. But from what I have played of it, it's also really good..

DISLIKES:

Some maps were just too big or too small.. The Gunsmith was good, way better than mw2 and mw3. But I didn't like that the leveling was too slow, so you have to burn double up tokens that you saved up. The only good gamemode in multiplayer was 1v1 me bro. The others were ok, but they didn't appeal to me..
If you're thinking of buying this game, wait till it goes on sale, it's a amazing game, but not worth $60 bucks..

EDIT: So I just found out that they're are cheaters in this game, but I haven't found any cheats that can actually do harm to you, only just wall hacks and aim bot..

CONCLUSION:

9.5/10

My Year-Long Struggle Against a Call of Duty False Permanent Ban
November 26, 2023
Over the past year, I’ve found myself in an unexpected and relentless battle, not in the digital arenas of Call of Duty, but against an unseen, unyielding opponent: a false permanent ban. This isn’t just my story; it’s a glimpse into a widespread issue that has quietly affected thousands of players. It started with a simple misstep by an anti-cheat system and spiraled into a complex ordeal that questions the balance between vigilance against cheating and the rights of innocent gamers.

In the following account, I’ll take you through the twists and turns of my efforts to seek justice, the broader implications for the community, and the pressing need for accountability and change in Activision’s approach to fair play. Finally, I’ll share my optimism that new owner Microsoft can rise to the occasion and fix this ongoing issue.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) Review: A Triumphant Reboot

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) marks a bold return to form for the legendary first-person shooter franchise, delivering a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and refined gameplay that sets a new standard for the series. Infinity Ward's reboot reimagines the classic Modern Warfare storyline, bringing it into the contemporary world with a fresh yet familiar feel.

Story and Characters:
The campaign of Modern Warfare is nothing short of spectacular. It introduces players to a gritty, morally complex narrative that feels ripped from the headlines. The story centers around the fight against a global threat, featuring a mix of new and returning characters. Captain Price, a beloved figure from the original series, makes a triumphant comeback, redefined with a depth that makes him more compelling than ever. The narrative delves into the gray areas of modern warfare, presenting tough moral choices and thought-provoking scenarios that resonate long after the credits roll.

Graphics and Sound:
From a visual standpoint, Modern Warfare is a masterpiece. The game leverages a new engine that produces stunningly realistic environments, lifelike character models, and breathtaking effects. Whether you’re navigating through war-torn cities or sneaking through dense forests, the level of detail is astonishing. Coupled with an impeccable sound design that captures the chaos of battle with precision, the immersive experience is unparalleled. The voice acting, particularly Barry Sloane's portrayal of Captain Price, adds a layer of authenticity and emotion that draws players deeper into the story.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
The gameplay in Modern Warfare is finely tuned, offering a satisfying blend of tactical strategy and fast-paced action. The gunplay is tight and responsive, with each weapon feeling unique and impactful. The game introduces a variety of mission types, from intense firefights to stealth operations, ensuring that the campaign remains dynamic and engaging throughout. The addition of realistic mechanics, such as mounting weapons on surfaces and the use of night vision in certain missions, enhances the tactical depth and realism of the game.

Multiplayer and Special Ops:
Multiplayer is where Modern Warfare truly shines. The revamped multiplayer mode features a range of maps and modes that cater to different playstyles, from traditional 6v6 matches to the large-scale Ground War mode. The customization options for weapons and operators are extensive, allowing players to tailor their loadouts to their preferences. The game also introduces the Gunsmith system, providing an unprecedented level of customization for weapon attachments and performance.

Special Ops mode offers cooperative gameplay experiences, presenting challenging missions that require teamwork and strategy. While the difficulty can be daunting, the sense of accomplishment upon completing these missions is immensely rewarding.

Conclusion:
Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) is a resounding success, revitalizing the franchise with a fresh yet faithful reboot. Its compelling narrative, stunning visuals, and refined gameplay mechanics set a new benchmark for first-person shooters. Whether you’re a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer, Modern Warfare offers an experience that is both thrilling and unforgettable. Infinity Ward has crafted a game that not only pays homage to its roots but also boldly steps into the future of the genre.

Rating: 9.5/10

Farah is awesome. Loved her character, her very dark story and the whole character design (which is of course based on actress Claudia Doumit).

That was my favourite part. As for the rest of the game... everybody knows what to expect by now. Some missions are awesome (and among CoDs greatest hits by now), but there are a lot of filler missions in my opinion. A lot of it just felt kinda hollow and I often found my self thinking something like: The OG Modern Warfare might have outdated graphics, but the action, suspension and scripts were just as good and better that many years ago.

The best missions where these that tried a bit more "realism" (I know, I know) and took  inspiration from real events: Terror attacks in London, the wars in the Levant, the Bin Laden raid, the Benghazi attacks or a simple (but very well made) raid on a civilian house by Special Forces. At least thats what I personally assume the inspirations were.

[h1]Activision does not deserve your money.[/h1]

I played this game on PS4 back when it was a new game, and it was great. I bought it on sale for PC, and it is the worst port I have ever played, hands down. Horrid graphical bugs, always-online DRM even in the fucking singleplayer, constant freezing, stuttering, and crashing. The game will not even start anymore, it just crashes when you get to the "Connecting to Online Services" screen. What a complete joke.

The game itself is actually one of the better releases in the line of annual slop Activision pushes out, which I guess is remarkable given how bad each one has been for the past decade or so. Campaign story ranged from mediocre to godawful, but is held up by the satisfying animations, gunplay, and the design of the missions. Clean House is the best mission in the entire franchise because it does exactly what it needs to; It drops the formulaic 'Sgt. Call of Duty kills 1,000 bad guys and wins' bravado and is a mission about killing a few people in a tight sequence that maintains tension throughout. That mission and "Going Dark" alone raised my rating for it by at least 3 points.

Then there's multiplayer. I just miss when CoD had an art style and multiple factions with distinct looks. Black Ops 2 was the last time this franchise ever actually tried to innovate in something other than microtransactions and DLC bundles. At first it was actually trying to be realistic with no flashy weapon skins or ridiculous operator customization, but now it's just a mess of anime guns and warzone battle passes. Other than that, gunplay is really good, and the gunsmith feature is paradise for gun autists like me. 

I never played Spec-Ops, but from what I've seen it's just downgraded from 2011 MW3. Not good.

Overall: 7/10
This Shitty Port: 0/10

I picked this game up during the current sale for about 20 Euros, mainly to play the campaign. I had played multiplayer during the times the game had free trials from time to time, but I never actually bought it. Now, years later, I decided to play the campaign and it was worth it. From the variety of missions, gameplay, difficulty, graphics, music, visuals, to the overall vibe, it was brilliant. I still like Black Ops Cold War's campaign the most from the new generation of Call of Duty games, but that might change as I am planning to play Modern Warfare 2 and Modern Warfare 3's campaigns after this. And of course, we have Black Ops 6 rumored to be released this fall.

I guess I am in the minority of players who buy Call of Duty games to experience the campaigns before hopping onto multiplayer. But that's my review. If you are wondering if this game is worth considering, then yes, I recommend this game if you are looking to play the campaign. If you want to experience multiplayer, the newer titles have more populated servers.

este call of duty es una experiencia completamente diferente a cualquier otro call of duty, por lo menos en multijugador, el juego esta claramente basado en el gameplay que solia tener call of duty 4 modern warfare (2007), incluso los mismos mapas estan aqui, ahi el ''problema'' de este cod, los mapas son mas grandes de lo comun y asi son todos en su mayoria, es muy dificil en una partida sacarte mas de 20 o 30 kills por que mas de la mitad del tiempo estas corriendo  y muchos enemigos estaran escondiendose en un rincon o dando vueltas por una misma zona pequeña, campeando en un techo etc... , el movimiento en si es bastante agil, y comodo de mover, tiene unas graficas que se mantienen al nivel este 2024 logrando verse moderno todavia apesar de tener 5 años desde su salida, una de las cosas que no me gustaron fue la carencia de modos de juego, en si hay bastantes, como los puede ser, domination, hardcore, 1v1, gungame, (modos basicos de call of duty) pero por ejemplo, carece de un modo como podria ser ''hyper cranked'' del nuevo mw3 o nuketown 24/7 de cold war, en si algo que logre sacarte un poquito del gamplay  mas lento de los mapas grandes que abundan en este juego.
 en pocas palabras si quieres una partida mas llena de accion y balazos a lo estupido deberias irte por otro call of duty, no quiere decir que es malo, pero si tiene un gameplay diferente a los demas... de echo el juego es muy bueno y apezar de esto me eh viciado por horas jugandolo, es bastante adictivo y satisfactorio al hacer kills, pero me gustaria mas precencia de mapas pequeños en el juego, aveces uno se confunde a donde tienes que ir en un mapa tan grande con poca gente por ejemplo... te llega a confundir bastante y es jodido estar desorientado, fuera de eso el gameplay es bastante bueno y en general un muy buen cod.

Title: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) - A Riveting Return to Form

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) is nothing short of a triumphant return to the roots of the franchise, delivering a gritty and intense first-person shooter experience that reignites the flames of nostalgia while simultaneously pushing the boundaries of modern gaming.

From the moment you step into the boots of various operators in the campaign, you're thrust into a world of geopolitical intrigue and high-stakes combat. The narrative weaves a complex tale that feels ripped from the headlines, exploring themes of terrorism, espionage, and the moral gray areas of modern warfare. The characters are well-developed, each with their own motivations and struggles, adding depth to an already gripping storyline.

Visually, Modern Warfare is a masterpiece. The game's graphics are stunning, with breathtakingly realistic environments and meticulously detailed character models. Whether you're navigating the war-torn streets of a Middle Eastern city or infiltrating a Russian military base under the cover of darkness, every moment feels immersive and cinematic.

But where Modern Warfare truly shines is in its gameplay. The gunplay is tight and responsive, offering a wide array of authentic weapons to choose from, each with its own distinct feel and handling. The addition of realistic ballistics and bullet penetration mechanics adds a layer of tactical depth, rewarding players who take the time to master their arsenal.

The multiplayer component of Modern Warfare is equally impressive, offering a diverse selection of game modes and maps to keep players engaged for hours on end. Whether you prefer the frenetic pace of Team Deathmatch or the strategic depth of Search and Destroy, there's something here for everyone. And with the introduction of the Gunfight mode, which pits teams of two against each other in intense, close-quarters battles, there's always a new challenge to tackle.

Of course, no Call of Duty game would be complete without its iconic Zombies mode, and Modern Warfare delivers in spades. The cooperative multiplayer experience pits players against hordes of the undead in a variety of unique and challenging scenarios, offering endless replayability for those looking for a break from the traditional multiplayer grind.

In conclusion, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) is a tour de force of modern gaming, blending stunning visuals, engaging storytelling, and addictive gameplay into one unforgettable package. Whether you're a longtime fan of the franchise or a newcomer looking for your next adrenaline rush, this game is not to be missed.

Modern Warfare 2019 marked a pivotal moment for the franchise, yet it faced undue criticism from some corners. Let's set the record straight: this game brought many disillusioned fans back into the fold, and for good reason.

First off, let's talk about what it got right. The gunplay and movement are undeniably the best in the series. It's fluid, responsive, and adds a new layer of immersion to every firefight. And let's not forget about the graphics and sound design—truly unmatched in the genre.

However, it's not without its flaws. Some players found the maps lacking, and the player health system held the game back slightly. Additionally, the implementation of strict skill-based matchmaking (SBMM) left many feeling frustrated and stifled their enjoyment of the game.

But despite these shortcomings, Modern Warfare 2019 deserves recognition for its achievements. It revitalized the franchise, bringing back old fans and attracting new ones in the process. And while it may not be perfect, it's certainly one of the best Call of Duty game in my book. Warzone 1 and verdansk was based on this game and it felt great. After a few matches, I hopped on customs to mess with the guns and gunsmith system and was reminded why this is honestly peak COD. The gunsmith system was the greatest addition to COD, no doubt. That doesn't mean every COD should use it, but it's amazing when done with thought like here. And not only that, but the bots are so damn human. They're... not very smart humans, but they're leagues better than old COD bots and they do things real players would do. I think my second death was to a bot who decided to say "F*ck it, let's become a snail" and crawled on the floor where I never would have expected a bot. They aren't snapping onto me like a radar too, which is just nice. It really felt like a match where I just happened to be the best player.  I've never had this kind of fun just fighting bots.

And I'll be honest, I bought this COD because it's basically the last one to mostly use real firearm names. The M4, AK47, AN94, AUG, MP5, all those iconic guns with their iconic and real looks.

If the rumored Black Ops series COD coming out this year isn't a good showing, I probably won't be buying anymore Call of Duty titles, exception being MW3 Remastered whenever they decide to release that.

Back when this game came out the first time, I didn't have a PC or console that played the game. I got to play the Multiplayer beta for this game by convincing a friend of mine to lend me his Xbox One for the beta duration. I just was awed by the visuals and the surprisingly decent campaign through YouTube videos and the beta looked incredible on such dated hardware.

I built my gaming PC in December of 2019, and Warzone 1 released in March of 2020 as a free to play title. I was hooked.

Literally spent days sinking into the battle royale, increasing my stress levels, and winning several Warzone matches in 2020, sadly due to the intensity of Verdansk I stepped away from Warzone just to keep my blood pressures down. This is one of the few games to truly make me feel that way, and I still to this day miss Verdansk.

While being a free to play title for Warzone, the base game's multiplayer would be available for free play users for weekends, I would spend most of those weekends in the multiplayer, just grinding away at a masterpiece of a multiplayer. 

I got a PS5 shortly after it's release in December of 2020, and this was immediately one of the first pre-owned titles I snagged from GameStop for the PS5's backwards compatibility mode. I have over 400 hours listed on PSN for this game and probably 100+ on Xbox, majority being MW multiplayer depending on console availability (I preferred to play Warzone on PC).

Years later, after a semi-acceptable MW2 in 2022 and a colossal disaster of MW3 2023, I still jump into multiplayer of this title on the PS4 version, waiting for this game to go on sale on PC so I could get a better experience. 

I finally grabbed it for PC proper during 2024's Steam FPS Fest, and I have already fallen in love again with the improved visuals and framerate over the PS4 version. 

To me, I envision this game similar to be like that one young wild girl that you keep telling yourself is trouble, you can see the red flags that will happen in the future, you have already done everything under the sun with her, and you should just probably move on. Find another girl who is more traditional, down to earth, maybe start a family. But no matter how much you try to convince yourself to cut her off, you just can't get yourself to do it and send another "hey you busy?" text.

If you are entering this game for the first time, I will say its a little rough around the edges given the condition Activision has left it in, but it easily stands among the top of the Call of Duty series as a whole, it definitely stands better than its successors, and is definitely deserving of your time, the fantastic although short story is still wonderful all these years later, and while more complicated to learn that older titles in the series (like Bo2), the multiplayer is bar none one of the best experiences I have ever played. I wish I could feel it again for the first time, don't miss that opportunity for yourself.

I bought this game purely for the singleplayer. It was on sale at USD$20
I finished it in 5 hours. So keep that in mind...

No spoilers ahead. But here's my experience for anyone interested

Starting it up. I'm greeted with a bunch of T&Cs I couldn't reject.
Forced to sign up for an activision account. Gave it a fake email.
Jumped straight into single player and the first few missions would be really tough for a newcomer.
No tutorial, no agility course, you go straight into the action.

Starting out it was great fun and a challange for me... I was enjoying the story and the CQB combat.
But the turning point was a mission when you see the war from a child's perspective. 
The initial cutscenes from the child perspective was great...
But afterwards... everything went to shit.
I hated the part where as a child, you had to attack an NPC, hide, and repeat the whole rigmaroll 3 times
I hid for a good 10 minutes until I pressed TAB and saw the objective... Like seriously!?
Made no sense. And gameplay wise there was ABSOLUTELY NO INDICATION you were supposed to attack.

Then the combat went completely off the rails.
There were sections in dark mines with no torchlight or NVGs... Enemies started spawning right in front of me. And they introduced a new enemy type called a "juggernaught" which ambushed me in a small room. I emptied a whole 30 round clip on its head and it didn't die. I end up dying 4 times before the game told me to flashbang the enemy.
Flashbang, the enemy, while I'm trapped in the same room?
ARE. YOU. SERIOUS?
and also. SERIOUSLY? A BOSS FIGHT THAT IS JUST A BULLET SPONGE!?

The missions afterwards were obviously rushed. My team AI would often completely bug out and I had to kill all the enemies on my own for them to advance...
I checked gameplay from YouTube after my playthrough but I have yet to find similar bugs encountered by others...

Me personally? I love the new rehash and the characters from the original trilogy but thats my personal bias... 
Anyone new to the Call of Duty franchise would do better starting from the original Call of Duty 4 Modern Warfare...
Now since I only paid $20 I'm overall "OK" with my experience.
But this is a $60 game! I will NOT recommend this to anyone full price.
